fields.name: qgis_irmt_3b256b21_d838_4965_b8e3_a6e691f7c03f

fields.abstract_en:
A shapefile containing socioeconomic indicators for parroquias of Quito was loaded in QGIS.
Loss data exported as csv by the OpenQuake Engine was imported by the IRMT and aggregated by the geometries defined in the shapefile.
A hierarchical integrated risk model was defined, combining 3 population-related socioeconomic indicators and 3 economy-related ones.
All combined variables were scaled from 0 to 1, to be made commensurable.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_bfa0ba11_3c91_4b77_8932_08632b829b5b

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Argentina at the Comuna (P2) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_babf9a20_8564_4988_bed7_1256062204db
fields.purpose_en: Earthquake risk assessment, Earthquake risk communication, Social vulnerability assessment

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Bolivia at the Municipio (P3) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_dfd324ad_e45e_40cb_929e_8e844f470756
fields.purpose_en: Earthquake risk assessment, Earthquake risk communication, Social vulnerability assessment

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Colombia at the Municipio (P2) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_38863577_5e0d_4d0b_8cab_6f0b7bdeef95
fields.purpose_en: Earthquake risk assessment, Earthquake risk communication, Social vulnerability assessment

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Ecuador at the Parroquia (P3) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_5f67abd7_1a6b_4da1_9221_c5600b13815d
fields.purpose_en: Earthquake risk assessment, Earthquake risk communication, Social vulnerability assessment

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Peru at the Distrito (P3) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_5a92c817_46c7_4fce_8aa8_c893a3178f24
fields.purpose_en: Earthquake risk assessment, Earthquake risk communication, Social vulnerability assessment

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Venezuela at the Parroquia (P3) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_edad55bc_a740_4f17_969c_502137ba34b8
fields.purpose_en: Earthquake risk assessment, Earthquake risk communication, Social vulnerability assessment

fields.abstract_en: The following is an integrated earthquake risk assessment for Chile at the Comuna (P3) level of geography. This assessment is a "work in progress" as weights will be applied to the data. The latter is being conducted within the respective country. Integrated risk is defined here as the combination of average annual losses to residential infrastructure with a composite index of social vulnerability. A composite index of social vulnerability is a combination of data that aims to measure characteristics within social systems that create the potential for loss and the differential ability to mitigate, respond to, and recover from damaging earthquake events. An integrated risk index provides a "broad brush" approach to highlighting areas where earthquake losses are most likely to occur coupled with the location of populations that are least likely to be able to be able to cope with such losses.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_68e193db_7522_4024_b44d_fc591da86d61

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia.  

This layer represents results of a single level SoVI model for the entire Province.  It does not reflect variations that are known to exist from region to region based on community type.  Subsequent versions of the model will incorporate multi-level variations for 7 distinct community types. These include:
SAC Type 1: Urban Metropolitan Centre
SAC Type 2: Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions
SAC Type 3:Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions
SAC Type 4:Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence
SAC Type 5:Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence
SAC Type 6:Rural District with weak metropolitan influence
SAC Type 7:Rural District with no metropolitan influence
fields.supplemental_information_en:
{
  "irmt_plugin_version": "1.7.15",
  "license": "CC BY-SA 3.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/)",
  "title": "SoVI-BC_Version1",
  "zone_label_field": "SVI",
  "abstract": "The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia.  The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: \n1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre \n2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions \n3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions \n4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence \n5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence \n6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence \n7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence \n There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: \nA.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) \nB.      Economic System (8 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) \nC.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) \nD.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities\nWe have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we have assign in our multi-level hierarchical model (28 layers in total). Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment.  We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement. ",

fields.name: qgis_irmt_7d88c3fb_2b41_4a25_9029_adf4cd6fae90
fields.purpose_en: Testing and validation

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia.  The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (8 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities)
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment.  We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_bd3df39e_76ec_4be7_ab63_b20e9c352ea4

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) 
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we have assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

    "abstract": "The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: \n1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre \n2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions \n3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions \n4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence \n5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence \n6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence \n7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence \nThere are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: \nA.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) \nB.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) \nC.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) \nD.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) \nWe have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we have assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement. ",

fields.name: qgis_irmt_f1690d92_76df_4cac_95e0_e43fcad729e9

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) 
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) \nC.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) \nD.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) \nWe have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement. ",

  "title": "SoVI-BC_SAC3_Version1",
  "zone_label_field": "SVI",
  "abstract": "The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: \n1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre \n2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions \n3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions \n4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence \n5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence \n6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence \n7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence \nThere are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: \nA.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) \nB.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) \nC.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) \nD.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) \nWe have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement. ",

fields.name: qgis_irmt_5457e57b_40aa_4505_ac82_bd33146c28a3

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) 
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_7fc1adf7_1474_490a_aba8_6638610621cb

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) 
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_0c7902da_535c_4dea_95c5_6a241d78f2bf

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) 
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

fields.name: qgis_irmt_a1edb3dc_a277_4cb5_a19b_cba328dcd201

fields.abstract_en:
The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: 
1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre 
2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions 
3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions 
4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence 
5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence 
6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence 
7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence 
There are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: 
A.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) 
B.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) 
C.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) 
D.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) 
We have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement.

    "zone_label_field": "SVI",
    "abstract": "The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) is working in partnership with the Global Earthquake Model Foundation (GEM) to develop a regional multi-level Social Vulnerability (SoVI) model for British Columbia. Outputs will be incorporated into an integrated earthquake risk assessment for the Province of British Columbia. The SoVI-BC model reflects underlying socioeconomic drivers of risk for 7 distinct community archetypes: \n1.       Urban Metropolitan Centre \n2.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with administrative subdivisions \n3.       Urban Agglomeration Area (Pop>10,000) with no administrative subdivisions \n4.       Exurban Regional District with strong metropolitan influence \n5.       Exurban Regional District with moderate metropolitan influence \n6.       Rural District with weak metropolitan influence \n7.       Rural District with no metropolitan influence \nThere are separate SoVI models for each of these 7 community archetypes.  Each regional SoVI model is defined in terms of four major system components: \nA.      Social System (20 variables: age, family characteristics, language, education, etc.) \nB.      Economic System (16 variables: household income, individual income, employment status, etc.) \nC.      Community Health (13 variables: illness, access to health care, quality of life, etc.) \nD.      Built Environment (4 variables: seismic safety level, proximity to essential facilities) \nWe have run PCA on each of the 4 model components for all 7 community typologies to get weightings that we will assign in our multi-level hierarchical model. Version 1 of the SoVI-BC model is now ready in draft mode for review and comment. We welcome your input on model design and suggestions for improvement. ",
    "title": "SovI-BC_SAC_7_Version1",

fields.abstract_en: The county boundary for Frederick County, Maryland
fields.supplemental_information_en: This data is utitlized by Frederick County for mapping purposes.The boundary depicted is not based on a legal survey of the county boundary and may be inaccurate in areas. The original source of the data is unknown, although it is believed that the data was acquired from the State of Maryland.This layer includes information from the U.S Census bureau pertainining to the toatal area of land and water per sq miles within the county as well as the year the county was founded.
fields.name: countyline
fields.purpose_en: To depict the boundary of Frederick County, Maryland.
fields.constraints_other_en: Frederick County employees have unrestricted use of the data, but are not permitted to distribute the data in its raw format to external groups or individuals without consent from the Enterprise GIS Manager.   For governmental agencies and private groups or individuals provided with the data, use is in accordance with Frederick County, Maryland's GIS License Agreement.  While efforts have been made to ensure the accuracy of the data, Frederick County accepts no responsibility for errors, omissions, or positional inaccuracies in the data.  Frederick County makes no warranty, express or implied, and disclaims all implied warranties of merchantability, integration, title, and fitness of the GIS data for a particular purpose.  Reliance on the data is at the risk of the user.

fields.abstract_en: The county boundary for Frederick County, Maryland
fields.supplemental_information_en: This data is utitlized by Frederick County for mapping purposes.The boundary depicted is not based on a legal survey of the county boundary and may be inaccurate in areas. The original source of the data is unknown, although it is believed that the data was acquired from the State of Maryland.This layer includes information from the U.S Census bureau pertainining to the toatal area of land and water per sq miles within the county as well as the year the county was founded.

fields.abstract_en:
Seismic hazard map for Nepal.  Mean Peak Ground Acceleration (g) 10% probability of exceedence in 50 years.

V. L. Stevens, S. N. Shrestha, D. K. Maharjan; Probabilistic Seismic Hazard Assessment of Nepal. Bulletin of the Seismological Society of America ; 108 (6): 3488–3510. doi: https://doi.org/10.1785/0120180022

-----

Please see the METEOR project page https://meteor-project.org

fields.abstract_en:
Seismic Hazard Map showing mean Peak Ground Acceleration (PGA) in g for a 10% probability of exceedence in 50 years for the country of Tanzania.

This map was produced using the GEM OpenQuake engine using the SSAHARA model produced, please see https://hazard.openquake.org/gem/models/SSA/ for further details.

----

Please see the METEOR project page https://meteor-project.org

fields.abstract_en: The county boundary for Frederick County, Maryland
fields.supplemental_information_en: This data is utitlized by Frederick County for mapping purposes.The boundary depicted is not based on a legal survey of the county boundary and may be inaccurate in areas. The original source of the data is unknown, although it is believed that the data was acquired from the State of Maryland.This layer includes information from the U.S Census bureau pertainining to the toatal area of land and water per sq miles within the county as well as the year the county was founded.
